overview: The purpose of this measure is to increase the tax on cigarettes and allocate the revenues for debt reduction for the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). Your Committee on Ways and Means has amended this measure by specifying that the increased tax revenues be deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). Furthermore, the measure now requires that, until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt).
appropriations: The measure has been amended to specify that increased tax revenues be deposited directly into the Hawaii cancer research special fund (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). Previously, the bill allocated the two-cent increase to the University of Hawaii for debt reduction purposes (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). The amendment now requires that until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues in the fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt).
agency_impact: The Committee on Ways and Means adopted amendments suggested by the University of Hawaiâ€˜i Cancer Center and the Department of the Attorney General (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). The amendment specifies that the increased tax revenues be deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund, which addresses the agencies' request for clarity and direct funding deposit (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). The Department of the Attorney General noted that Hawaii received over $36.4 million (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in MSA payments for fiscal year 2023-2024, highlighting the need for stable funding to maintain diligent enforcement efforts (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
economic_impact: Testimony indicates that plummeting cigarette tax revenues have jeopardized the revenue stream for debt service for revenue bonds sold to construct the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). Cigarette tax stamp revenues have fallen from over $116 million (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in fiscal year 2015-2016 to just over $70 million (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in fiscal year 2023-2024 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). Additionally, Hawaii received over $36.4 million (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Master Settlement Agreement (MSA) payments for fiscal year 2023-2024 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
policy_impact: The Committee on Ways and Means has amended this measure by specifying that the increased tax revenues be deposited into the Hawaii cancer research special fund (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). A second key amendment requires that, until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). These changes align with recommendations from the University of Hawai'i Cancer Center and the Department of the Attorney General to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
revenue_sources: A breakdown of the current taxing scheme for FY24 shows revenue distributions to several special funds from cigarette and tobacco taxes. Key distributions include $8,606,752 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) to the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund, $4,841,298 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) to the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund, and $5,379,220 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) each to the Community Health Centers Special Fund and the Trauma System Special Fund (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). The Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund received $1,032,810 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) and the Cigarette Tax Stamp Administrative Special Fund received $137,708 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY24 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
capital_expenditure_impact: This measure has been amended to require that, until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). This change directly addresses the funding for revenue bonds sold to construct the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii in 2010 (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). The UH Cancer Center had previously requested that 2.0 cents per cigarette be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: A significant long-term fiscal implication has been added to the measure. The bill now requires that until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues allocated to the Hawaii cancer research special fund must be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). This creates a dedicated funding stream for the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii's capital and maintenance costs for nearly two decades beyond the initial six-year outlook.
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The Committee on Ways and Means has amended the measure, significantly altering the disposition of the proposed tax increase revenue. The key update is that the increased revenues will now be deposited directly into the Hawaii cancer research special fund, rather than being payable to the University of Hawaii (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). Furthermore, a new long-term requirement mandates that until June 30, 2041, all cigarette tax revenues in that fund must be used exclusively for debt service of capital expenditures and building maintenance (HB441_SD2_SSCR1706_.PDF.txt). New financial data includes a breakdown of FY24 revenue distributions to various special funds, such as $8,606,752 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund, and that the state received over $36.4 million (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in MSA payments for FY 2023-2024 (HB441_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
